messageBody:
Eric George wrote:

> JUnit users,
> I have written an article in which I describe a Testing Pattern which
> I call AbstractTest. The basic idea is to maximize reuse of tests
> written for an interface for every implementation of the interface.
>
> I have been using this technique for a while to good effect, but I would
> love to to get some feedback from this group on the issue. I am
> especially interested to hear about other approaches that people have
> used to accomplish the same goals.
>
> Read the full article here
> http://www.placebosoft.com/abstract-test.html
>

Great article, Eric!

Using this testing pattern effectively identifies any violations of the
Liskov Substitution Principle, which states that derived types must be
completely substitutable for their base types. In other words, the behavior
of derived types must remain unchanged from the client's perspective. The
consequences of violating LSP are that clients must know all the derivatives
of a base class. These clients must then be modified when a new subclass is
created. Adhering to LSP allows clients to remain open to extension, but
closed to modification, when a new subclass is introduced.

On a separate note, I'm not sure I would preclude concrete test classes from
overriding setUp() or tearDown(). Test fixtures are fundamental building
blocks of JUnit tests. If in fact a concrete test forgets to call
super.setUp() in its overridden setUp(), then the test will fail anyway. The
advantages of adding to the fixture for concrete tests seems to outweigh the
potential for abuse, in my opinion.

Thanks for sharing this article!

Regards,

Mike
